meta.title: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
meta.author: C.S. Lewis

1.description: The youngest of the four Pevensie children. She is curious and adventurous, the first to discover the wardrobe during a game of hide-and-seek.

2.description: First to enter Narnia through the wardrobe. Met the faun Mr. Tumnus and had tea with him in his cave. She is brave and trusting, believing in the magic of Narnia.

4.description: Returns to Narnia with her siblings. Shows them the lamp-post and leads them to Mr. Tumnus's cave, only to find it ransacked.

17.description: Crowned Queen Lucy the Valiant at Cair Paravel. Rules Narnia for many years as one of the four monarchs.

1.description: The third child and younger son of the Pevensie family. He can be spiteful and doesn't believe Lucy's story about the wardrobe.

3.description: Follows Lucy into the wardrobe and meets the White Witch. She gives him enchanted Turkish Delight and makes him promise to bring his siblings to her.
3.role: Reluctant ally of the White Witch

8.description: Slips away from the Beavers' house to betray his siblings to the White Witch, hoping for Turkish Delight and to become a prince.

13.description: Rescued by Aslan's army and forgiven by his siblings. Learns about the deep consequences of betrayal and the power of redemption through Aslan's actions.

17.description: Crowned King Edmund the Just at Cair Paravel. Becomes known for his fairness and wisdom in judgment, having learned from his mistakes.

1.description: The second child and elder daughter of the Pevensie family. She is practical and cautious, initially skeptical about Lucy's claims about the wardrobe.

4.description: Enters Narnia with her siblings and begins to believe Lucy's story. Shows concern for their safety and Edmund's whereabouts.

12.description: Witnesses extraordinary events at the Stone Table with Lucy and shows great courage through a difficult night. Her loyalty and bravery shine through despite her natural caution.

17.description: Crowned Queen Susan the Gentle at Cair Paravel. Known for her kindness and wisdom, skilled with the bow given to her by Father Christmas.

1.description: The eldest of the four Pevensie children and natural leader of his siblings. He feels responsible for their safety and behavior.

4.description: Enters Narnia and takes charge of the situation when they discover Mr. Tumnus is missing. Shows leadership qualities and determination to help.

14.description: Leads the charge in the final battle against the White Witch's forces. Shows great courage and skill in combat with the sword and shield given by Father Christmas.

17.description: Crowned High King Peter the Magnificent at Cair Paravel. Rules as the highest of the four monarchs and becomes known for his noble leadership.

2.description: A faun with goat legs and a tail, carrying an umbrella and packages. He has a reddish skin, curly hair, a short pointed beard, and two horns. Lives in a cave with a fireplace and many books.

4.description: Captured by the White Witch's secret police for harboring a human child (Lucy). His cave is ransacked and a notice declares him under arrest for high treason.

17.description: Rescued and freed from the White Witch's spell. Becomes a loyal subject of the four monarchs and lives peacefully in Narnia.
17.role: Free faun and subject of the Kings and Queens

7.description: A great lion, the true King of Narnia and son of the Emperor-Over-the-Sea. The Beavers speak of him with reverence and explain that his return signals hope for Narnia's liberation.

12.description: Arrives at the Stone Table for a crucial meeting with the White Witch regarding Edmund's fate. Makes a momentous decision according to the Deep Magic of Narnia.

13.description: Returns due to the Deeper Magic, revealing that one who makes the ultimate willing sacrifice for another will be restored. More powerful than before.

17.description: Crowns the four Pevensie children as Kings and Queens of Narnia. Rules as the true sovereign with wisdom and justice, bringing the golden age to Narnia.

3.description: A tall, beautiful woman dressed entirely in white fur, riding a sleigh drawn by white reindeer. Claims to be the Queen of Narnia and has made it always winter but never Christmas.

8.description: Lives in a castle made of ice and snow. Reveals her cruelty when Edmund arrives - she gives him only dry bread and water instead of the feast she promised.

relationships.Maugrim: Commands as her chief of police

11.description: Her power begins to weaken as the eternal winter starts to break. Father Christmas arrives, signaling her spell is failing.

14.description: Is defeated in the final battle by the forces of good. Her reign of terror over Narnia comes to an end.

5.description: A beaver who approaches the children at the ruined cave of Mr. Tumnus. He shows them a handkerchief as a sign that he knew the faun.
5.role: Talking beaver and friend of Mr. Tumnus

6.description: Takes the children to his dam home where they meet Mrs. Beaver. He explains the situation in Narnia and tells them about Aslan's expected return.

7.description: Tells the children about the prophecy of four human children becoming Kings and Queens of Narnia, and explains Aslan's true identity as the son of the Emperor-Over-the-Sea.

6.description: A kindly female beaver who welcomes the children to their dam home. She provides them with a hearty meal and shows maternal care for their wellbeing.

7.description: Supports her husband in explaining the prophecy and Aslan's return. Shows practical wisdom about preparing for their journey to meet Aslan.

1.description: An elderly professor who owns the large country house where the Pevensie children are staying during the war. He has a study full of books and appears to be a learned man.
1.role: Host and guardian of the children

17.description: Believes Lucy's story about the wardrobe when the children return. He hints that he knows more about Narnia than he initially let on, suggesting he may have been there himself.

1.description: The Professor's stern housekeeper who gives the children a tour of the house and warns them not to bother the Professor or make noise.

10.description: A jolly, bearded figure in red robes who appears when the White Witch's power begins to weaken. He brings gifts to the children and explains that his presence means the witch's spell is breaking.
10.role: Magical gift-giver and herald of change

4.description: The chief wolf of the White Witch's secret police. His notice is found at Mr. Tumnus's cave, declaring the faun under arrest for high treason.
4.role: Chief of the White Witch's secret police

8.description: A large, savage wolf who serves the White Witch with fierce loyalty. He guards her and carries out her cruel orders.

11.description: Defeated by Peter in battle when he threatens Susan and Lucy. This marks Peter's first act of courage as a warrior.

3.description: A dwarf who serves as the White Witch's driver, operating her sleigh drawn by white reindeer.
3.role: Servant and driver of the White Witch

8.description: Continues to serve the White Witch faithfully at her castle, helping with her evil plans.

5.description: A talking robin who guides the children through the forest toward Mr. Beaver. Shows that not all of Narnia's creatures serve the White Witch.

14.description: Half-human, half-horse creatures who fight in the final battle against the White Witch. They are skilled archers and warriors.
Magical horse-like creatures with single horns who join Aslan's army in the final battle against evil.

12.description: Great cats who are among Aslan's followers and witness important events at the Stone Table.

14.description: Great birds who fight from the air in the final battle, providing aerial support for Aslan's forces.
Tree-spirits who emerge from their trees to join the battle against the White Witch. They represent nature's awakening from her spell.
Water-spirits who join the battle, representing the rivers and streams freed from the White Witch's winter.
Loyal talking dogs who fight bravely in Aslan's army against the forces of evil.
Noble talking horses who serve as mounts and warriors in the final battle.

17.description: Talking badgers who become loyal subjects of the four monarchs in the golden age of Narnia.

13.description: Small talking mice who show exceptional loyalty to Aslan during the events at the Stone Table.

17.description: Talking rabbits who live peacefully in Narnia under the rule of the four monarchs.

8.description: Savage wolves who serve as the White Witch's secret police and enforcers throughout Narnia.

14.description: Fight in the final battle on the side of the White Witch against Aslan's forces.
Evil spirits that fight for the White Witch in the final battle.
Malicious spirits that serve the White Witch in the final battle against Aslan's army.
Large, brutish creatures who fight for the White Witch in her final battle.
Bull-headed creatures who serve the White Witch as warriors in the final battle.
Wicked creatures who fight for the White Witch, living up to their name with their cruelty.
Evil witch-like creatures who serve the White Witch in her army.
Evil spirits who join the White Witch's forces in the final battle.
Ghostly beings that serve the White Witch as part of her dark army.
Terrifying creatures whose very name describes their nature, fighting for the White Witch.
Fire-spirits who serve the White Witch despite being creatures of heat in her world of eternal winter.
Mischievous spirits who fight on the side of evil in the White Witch's army.
Evil creatures who serve in the White Witch's army during the final battle.
Wild, savage creatures who fight for the White Witch in her final battle.
Giant-like creatures who serve the White Witch as formidable warriors.

2.description: Half-human, half-goat creatures like Mr. Tumnus. They have been oppressed under the White Witch's rule but maintain their good nature.

14.description: Join Aslan's army in the final battle, fighting for their freedom from the White Witch's tyranny.
Creatures similar to fauns who join the battle for Narnia's liberation.
Noble dwarfs who fight for Aslan against the White Witch, unlike the dwarf who serves her.
Large, gentle giants who fight on Aslan's side in the final battle.
Large water birds who join the aerial forces in Aslan's army.

17.description: Noble talking deer who become subjects of the four monarchs during the golden age.

7.description: The father of Aslan and ultimate ruler over all. He is the source of the Deep Magic and represents the highest authority in all the worlds.
7.role: Ultimate sovereign and father of Aslan

17.description: A legendary white stag that appears in Narnia and grants wishes to those who catch it. Its appearance leads the four monarchs back to the lamp-post and ultimately back to England.

14.description: A noble centaur who serves as one of Aslan's chief commanders in the battle against the White Witch. He is brave, skilled in combat, and deeply loyal to Aslan.

13.description: A friendly giant who was turned to stone by the White Witch but is freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.

14.description: Fights valiantly in the final battle, using his great size and strength to help defeat the White Witch's forces.

3.description: White reindeer that draw the White Witch's sleigh through the snowy landscape of Narnia.

13.description: Three talking bears who were turned to stone by the White Witch and freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.
A talking leopard who was petrified by the White Witch but freed by Aslan from her castle.
A great stone lion in the White Witch's courtyard who was brought back to life by Aslan's breath.
A pack of talking dogs who were turned to stone by the White Witch but freed by Aslan.
Several tree-spirits who were turned to stone by the White Witch and freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.
A faun who was petrified by the White Witch but freed by Aslan. Represents the oppressed creatures of Narnia.

14.description: A wise talking owl who participates in the final battle as part of Aslan's aerial forces.
Dark birds that serve the White Witch as spies and messengers, fighting in her army.
Night creatures that serve the White Witch in her dark army during the final battle.

13.description: A good giant who was turned to stone by the White Witch but freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.
A young dwarf who was petrified by the White Witch but freed by Aslan, representing the good dwarfs of Narnia.

14.description: Fierce talking boars who fight bravely for Aslan in the final battle against the White Witch.

17.description: Nimble talking squirrels who become cheerful subjects of the four monarchs during the golden age of Narnia.
Small talking moles who live peacefully underground in Narnia during the golden age of the four monarchs.
Spiky talking hedgehogs who become peaceful subjects of the four monarchs during Narnia's golden age.
Clever talking foxes who become cunning but loyal subjects during the golden age of Narnia.
Playful talking otters who live by Narnia's rivers and streams during the peaceful reign of the four monarchs.

14.description: Savage shapeshifters who fight for the White Witch in her army of evil creatures during the final battle.
Venomous snakes that serve the White Witch as deadly warriors in her evil army.

13.description: A centaur who was turned to stone by the White Witch but freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.
A unicorn that was petrified by the White Witch but restored to life by Aslan and joins the final battle.
A noble stag that was turned to stone by the White Witch but freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.
A talking horse that was petrified by the White Witch but brought back to life by Aslan.

14.description: Carrion birds that serve the White Witch as aerial scouts and fighters in her evil army.
Ghostly spirits that haunt the battlefield fighting for the White Witch's dark army.
Strange fungal creatures that serve the White Witch in her army of unnatural beings.
Evil dwarfs who fight for the White Witch, contrasting with the good dwarfs who serve Aslan.
Malevolent giants who serve the White Witch as massive warriors in her army.

2.description: A solitary lamp-post standing in the snowy woods of Narnia, providing light in the darkness. It marks the border between Narnia and the world of the wardrobe.

17.description: The lamp-post serves as the gateway back to England for the adult monarchs, leading them to the wardrobe and their return home.

7.description: An ancient stone table on a hilltop where Aslan gathers his forces. It is covered with strange writing and has deep significance in Narnia's magic.

13.description: The Stone Table cracks and breaks when the Deep Magic is fulfilled, symbolizing a great change in Narnia's destiny.

16.description: The ancient castle by the sea that serves as the royal palace of Narnia, where the four children are crowned as Kings and Queens.
16.role: Royal castle and seat of power

17.description: Giants from the north of Narnia who are mentioned as subjects that the four monarchs deal with during their reign.
People from the neighboring country of Archenland who have dealings with the Narnian monarchs during their reign.
People from the southern country of Calormen who are mentioned as having interactions with Narnia during the reign of the four monarchs.

13.description: A badger that was turned to stone by the White Witch but freed by Aslan from her castle courtyard.
Several squirrels that were petrified by the White Witch but brought back to life by Aslan.
A rabbit that was turned to stone by the White Witch but restored to life by Aslan's breath.
A small mouse that was petrified by the White Witch but freed by Aslan from her castle.

12.description: The ancient magical law that governs Narnia, written on the Stone Table. It demands that every traitor's life belongs to the White Witch.

13.description: Revealed to have an even deeper magic that supersedes it - when one makes the ultimate sacrifice for another, the magic itself can be reversed.

1.description: Visitors who come to see Professor Kirke's house, prompting the children to hide and leading to Lucy's discovery of the wardrobe.
An old wardrobe in the spare room of Professor Kirke's house, filled with mothballs and old coats.

2.description: Revealed to be a magical portal that leads from England to the land of Narnia when Lucy steps through it.

17.description: The gateway that brings the four adult monarchs back to England, returning them to their childhood selves.

3.description: Magical confection given to Edmund by the White Witch that creates an irresistible craving and makes him willing to betray his siblings.

12.description: A particularly noble leopard who serves as one of Aslan's chief companions and witnesses important events.

14.description: A mighty bear who leads other bears in the final battle, serving as one of Aslan's powerful warriors.
Skilled centaur warriors who serve as Aslan's elite archers in the final battle against the White Witch.
Swift eagles who serve as scouts and messengers for Aslan's army, providing aerial reconnaissance.
Noble unicorns who serve as elite guards and warriors in Aslan's army during the final battle.
Good giants who wield massive war hammers in the final battle, serving as Aslan's heavy assault troops.

17.description: The divine spirit of Narnia's great river who awakens during the golden age under the four monarchs.
Ancient forest deities who emerge during the golden age of Narnia under the rule of the four monarchs.

recaps.1: The four Pevensie children - Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy - are sent to stay with Professor Kirke in his large country house during World War II. Mrs. Macready, the housekeeper, shows them around and warns them not to disturb the Professor.
recaps.2: During a game of hide-and-seek, Lucy hides in an old wardrobe and discovers it leads to a snowy forest. She meets a faun named Mr. Tumnus who invites her for tea in his cave, where he reveals she is in a land called Narnia.
recaps.3: Lucy returns through the wardrobe but finds no time has passed. Her siblings don't believe her story about Narnia. Later, Edmund follows Lucy into the wardrobe and meets the White Witch, who gives him enchanted Turkish Delight and commands him to bring his siblings to her.
recaps.4: When Edmund returns, he lies about Narnia to spite Lucy. Eventually, all four children enter Narnia together while hiding from Mrs. Macready's tour group. They discover Mr. Tumnus has been arrested by the White Witch's secret police.
recaps.5: The children explore Narnia and meet a robin who guides them through the forest. They encounter Mr. Beaver, who knew Mr. Tumnus and shows them a handkerchief as proof of their friendship.
recaps.6: Mr. Beaver takes the children to his dam where they meet Mrs. Beaver. Over dinner, the Beavers explain that Narnia has been under the White Witch's spell of eternal winter, and that Aslan, the true king, is returning.
recaps.7: The Beavers tell the children about an ancient prophecy that four human children will become Kings and Queens of Narnia and defeat the White Witch. They explain that Aslan is the son of the Emperor-Over-the-Sea and the rightful ruler of Narnia.
recaps.8: Edmund slips away to betray his siblings to the White Witch. The others discover his absence and flee with the Beavers toward the Stone Table where Aslan is gathering his forces. Edmund reaches the White Witch's castle but finds her cold and cruel.
recaps.9: Edmund learns the White Witch's true nature when she gives him only bread and water instead of the feast she promised. Meanwhile, the other children travel through Narnia with the Beavers, noticing signs that the eternal winter is beginning to break.
recaps.10: As they journey, the group encounters Father Christmas, whose appearance signals that the White Witch's power is weakening. He gives the children magical gifts: Peter receives a sword and shield, Susan a bow and arrows, and Lucy a healing cordial and dagger.
recaps.11: The White Witch pursues Edmund and the children with her sleigh, but spring continues to arrive, making travel difficult for her. She eventually abandons the sleigh and continues on foot. Meanwhile, Peter kills Maugrim, the chief wolf, when he attacks Susan and Lucy.
recaps.12: The children reach Aslan at the Stone Table, where Edmund is reunited with his siblings and forgiven. That night, Aslan goes alone to meet with the White Witch for a private conference about Edmund's fate, while Susan and Lucy secretly follow him.
recaps.13: Susan and Lucy witness extraordinary events at the Stone Table through the night. At sunrise, something miraculous happens involving the ancient magic of Narnia. Aslan then goes to the White Witch's castle and frees her stone prisoners.
recaps.14: The final battle takes place as Peter leads Aslan's army against the White Witch's forces of evil creatures. Aslan arrives with his freed prisoners and joins the fight. The White Witch is defeated and killed, ending her reign over Narnia.
recaps.15: With the battle won, Aslan breathes on the petrified creatures to bring them back to life. The White Witch's spell over Narnia is completely broken, and the land begins to flourish again with spring and new life.
recaps.16: Aslan crowns the four children as Kings and Queens of Narnia at the ancient castle of Cair Paravel. Peter becomes High King Peter the Magnificent, Susan becomes Queen Susan the Gentle, Edmund becomes King Edmund the Just, and Lucy becomes Queen Lucy the Valiant.
recaps.17: The children rule Narnia for many years, growing into wise and beloved monarchs during a golden age. One day, while hunting the White Stag that grants wishes, they find the lamp-post and follow it back through the wardrobe, returning to England where no time has passed at all.
